title: How to Draw a Tree of Life

steps.title: Draw the roots of the tree.
steps.content: Draw the roots of the tree. These represent where you come from, and the people in life who have taught you the most. What anchors you when you are upset? Write it here. Your favourite place and your favourite song and book also go here. [5] X Research source You can return to your roots later if you want. The people of the First Nations may conceptualize the roots as still growing down and out, signifying that it is never too late to become more connected to your culture.

steps.title: Draw the ground.
steps.content: Draw the ground. Where do you currently live? What activities do you choose to do on a weekly basis? Write in the ground the answers to these questions. Is your ground stable, or frequently changing? Consider how you portray your ground - is it flat and smooth, or bumpy?

steps.title: Draw the trunk.
steps.content: Draw the trunk. On the trunk, write your values and skills, [6] X Research source your qualities, what you are committed to in life, and your purpose. [7] X Research source If it's hard to think of your skills, think about what people you love would say are your skills. Consider if there is any skill or talent you have which comes from your roots that you can add to your trunk. Sometimes, in tracing the history of things, you can add to your root system. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Draw the branches.
steps.content: Draw the branches. Write your hopes, dreams and wishes on the branches - for yourself and for other people. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Draw the leaves.
steps.content: Draw the leaves. On the leaves, write the names of important people in your life. They can be people who are still with you or people who have fallen away, like leaves in the wind. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Draw the fruit.
steps.content: Draw the fruit. The fruit represents the gifts you've been given or the legacies that have been passed onto you. [11] X Research source . The gifts can be things like kindnesses you want to remember, or significant material gifts, such as an 18th birthday present.

steps.title: Draw the seeds and flowers.
steps.content: Draw the seeds and flowers. The seeds and flowers represent gifts that you want to give to others. [12] X Research source They can be similar to gifts you have received, or very different. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Draw a compost heap.
steps.content: Draw a compost heap. This is an optional step. The compost heap represents any challenging, but important parts of your growth - physically, mentally and emotionally. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Consider storms, and how you can get through them.
steps.content: Consider storms, and how you can get through them. This is an optional step. Storms are challenges you face in life. Write down specific problems, and how you can overcome them, [15] X Research source using the skills you have identified in your trunk.

steps.title: Make sure the person is old enough to understand the purpose of the activity.
steps.content: Make sure the person is old enough to understand the purpose of the activity. They need to be able to share their story from their perspective, to think about where they come from, to think about what they are good at, to think about their hopes, dreams and wishes, and to think about the important people in their lives. Explain this if working with a child. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Ask your participant to think for a moment about trees with positive associations in their life and to share this with the group.
steps.content: Ask your participant to think for a moment about trees with positive associations in their life and to share this with the group. They are about to draw one such tree, [17] X Research source paying attention to its specific parts, drawing the tree step by step starting at the roots. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Show them example trees, including your own.
steps.content: Show them example trees, including your own.

steps.title: Give your participants paper, markers, and pencils and erasers.
steps.content: Give your participants paper, markers, and pencils and erasers. Ask them to draw the roots of the tree first, growing deep and strong underground. Then tell them that these represent where you come from, and the people in life who have taught you the most. What anchors you when you are upset? Write it here. Your favourite place and your favourite song and book also go here. [19] X Research source Reassure the participants that they can return to their roots later if they want.

steps.title: Ask your participants to draw the ground, and go through with them the same questions you did when you drew your ground.
steps.content: Ask your participants to draw the ground, and go through with them the same questions you did when you drew your ground. If you know them well you can help prompt them with examples of weekly activities that they can put in their ground.

steps.title: Ask your participants to draw the trunk.
steps.content: Ask your participants to draw the trunk. In addition to the questions you went through when you put your trunk together, you may wish to share an anecdote from your own life about a skill you have. Often, the roots or the ground will suggest skills or values to go in the trunk of the tree. Encourage your participants.

steps.title: Ask your participants to draw the branches, explaining that they represent your hopes, dreams and wishes for the future.
steps.content: Ask your participants to draw the branches, explaining that they represent your hopes, dreams and wishes for the future. For older participants, a broken branch or a tree hollow may represent an old dream that theyâ€™ve had to let go.

steps.title: Ask your participants to draw the leaves, with space to write the names of important people in their lives.
steps.content: Ask your participants to draw the leaves, with space to write the names of important people in their lives.

steps.title: Ask your participants to draw the fruit - be prepared to give examples of what the fruit represents.
steps.content: Ask your participants to draw the fruit - be prepared to give examples of what the fruit represents.

steps.title: Ask your participants to draw the seeds and flowers - gifts that the participant wants to give others.
steps.content: Ask your participants to draw the seeds and flowers - gifts that the participant wants to give others.

steps.title: Tell participants that they can draw a compost heap (optional).
steps.content: Tell participants that they can draw a compost heap (optional). If they want to put things that are negative that happened to them, they can still give some air and water to and turn them into good things with some work. Often, people in the compost heap are still in the rest of the tree too.

steps.title: Discuss storms with your participants, and how we can get through them by using the skills from our trunks (optional).
steps.content: Discuss storms with your participants, and how we can get through them by using the skills from our trunks (optional). Emphasise that a forest is stronger than a single tree alone, and praise the beautiful forest of life that your participants have created. Go around a circle and allow the participants to discuss their trees of life.
